choices.text: It is a type of portal-circulation
The renal artery divides into five segmental arteries before entering the hilum

questions.text: All the following are true regarding blood supply to the kidney, except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is correct the stellate veins are veins that lie beneath the fibrous tunica of the kidney and drain the superficial zone of the kidney. Option C is correct as renal artery divides into 5 segmental branches out of these 4 are anterior and are named as apical anterior, upper anterior, middle anterior and lower anterior and one posterior segmental artery. Option D is also correct as these segmental arteries are end arteries as they have no communication with each other. Option B as this is false because renal arterial system is not a type of portal circulation

questions.text: What is column of Bertini in kidney? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) as column of bertini are the tongue like papillary projection in kidney as an extension of renal cortex into medulla . Option A is wrong as they are not a form of renal tumor they are normal anatomical structure present is all the kidneys Option C is false they are neither calculus and nor do they promote calculus formation. You should remember that Randall Plaques are the calcifications in renal medulla and they predispose to stone formation in kidney .

questions.text: Renal collar which surrounds the aorta split by: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Renal collar which surrounds the Aorta is formed because of split in the renal vein and not the renal artery. Following figure demonstrates the renal collar formed by anterior and posterior renal vein around the Aorta. Renal collar is not formed by renal artery. Most common vascular anomaly of renal system is supernumerary renal artery. Isthumus of horse shoe kidney never splits around the aorta it lies just below the level of the IMA at the level of L3-L4

questions.text: 'Reverse J' deformity on IVP is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) as reverse J shaped deformity is seen in retrocaval ureter which occurs when the ureter passes behind the IVC. Retrocaval ureter deformity is caused by the abnormal persistence of Posterior cardiac vein. Other name for this reverse J deformity is Fish hook deformity. In congenital megaureter what you see is a dilated tortuous ureter on IVP In ureterocele there is cystic dilation of the terminal part of the ureter and it appears as a Adder head appearance on IVP and a filling defect in MCUG In VUR what we see is a reflux of urine in the ureter on MCUG . Intravenous pyelogram showing reverse-J deformity of right proximal ureter with dilatation along with hydronephrosis.

choices.text: Usually divided to gain access to renal pelvis

questions.text: Aberrant renal artery all true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) we do not usually divide the aberrant renal artery as if we do this it has a risk of leading to the ischemia of the kidney supplied by the aberrant renal artery. Option A is correct as it is more common in females Option B is correct aberrant renal artery is present mostly towards left side Option C is also correct as aberrant renal artery is one of the causes of the PUJ Obstruction and therfore it may cause hydronephrosis and it is important to diagnose it beforehand as if this is the cause we cannot go for endopyelotomy as a treatment option.

questions.text: Which is false of Horseshoe kidney? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Love and Bailey page 1399 Option A is false as spider leg appearance is an IVP finding of polycystic kidney disease and not horse shoe kidney. In horse shoe kidney. Lowermost calyx is pointing caudally and medially (Hand joining sign or hand shake sign). High insertion of ureter draping over midline isthmus (Flower vase sign). Option B is correct as due to improper rotation of kidney ureters pass over the isthmus and might be compressed at that point and lead to UTI or stone formation. Option C is correct as due to the fusion of the lower calyces they are reversed and on IVP appear as a typical hand shake appearance. Option D is also correct heminephrectomy is one of the treatment options for horse shoe kidney and was performed but now a days as far as the person is asymptomatic we do not treat this condition.

questions.text: Isthmus of horse shoe kidney is located at what level? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The isthmus of a horseshoe kidney is usually located lower than normal kidneys, because its ascent during development is halted by the inferior mesenteric artery, which originates around the L3 level. As a result, the isthmus typically lies at the L4–L5 level, anterior to the aorta and inferior vena cava.

questions.text: All are true in PUJO except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PUJ obstruction is more common on the left side and not the right side. Option A is correct as PUJ obstruction is more common in boys. Option B is also correct as PUJ obstruction occurs bilaterally in 10-30 % patients. Option D is correct as most common cause of PUJ Obstruction is intrinsic lesion that is defect in the peristalsis in a segment at the junction of renal pelvis and ureter.

questions.text: Most infants and children with PUJO present with: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) the most common cause of abdominal mass in children is hydronephrosis. As hydronephrosis develops slowly in children over the period of time it is unlikely to cause acute pain. Hematuria is usually not present in patients with hydronephrosis. Renal failure is the last stage of chronic hydronephrosis and patients present usually before the renal failure develops.

questions.text: Distention of abdomen with passage of large amount of urine is known as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as Distention of abdomen with pain followed by passage of large amount of urine which leads to reduction in pain and relieve of distention is known as Dietel’s crisis There is nothing which is known as Anderson Hynes crises, what we have is Anderson-hynes dismembered pyloroplasty which is infact a treatment for PUJ Obstruction Meteriorism is basically a colonic distention seen 24 to 48 hours after retroperitoneal hematoma and it occurs because of pressure over splanchanic nerves. The main cause of retroperitoneal hematoma is renal trauma Strangury (or stranguria) is the symptom characterized by painful, frequent urination of small volumes that are expelled slowly only by straining and despite a severe sense of urgency, usually with the residual feeling of incomplete emptying.

questions.text: A 3-years old girl presents with reccurent UTI. On USG shows hydronephrosis with filling defect and negative shadow of bladder with no ectopic orifice: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A girl with recurrent UTI, with hydronephrosis and filling defect in bladder is a typical finding of ureterocele. Ureterocele is basically a dilation of the distal intramural part of ureter which on MCUG appears as a filling defect and as a cobra head appearance or adder head appearance on IVP. Vesicoureteric reflux will show up as a reflux of dye into ureter and dilated tortuous ureter. Sacrococcygeal teratoma will present as a mass at sacrococcygeal region and not as hydronephrosis with recurrent UTI .

questions.text: Renal calculi associated with proteus infection: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Triple phosphate or struvite stone are the ones which are most commonly associated with urinary tract infection and the most common infection they are associated with is proteus.

questions.text: Nephrolithiasis occurs with the toxicity of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indinavir is a protease inhibitor which is used in the treatment of HIV infection. If this drug is taken for a longer duration of time it can lead to the formation of a radiolucent indinavir stone . Ritonavir, Saquinavir and Nelfinavir are the other drugs used for the treatment of HIV infection but are not associated with stone formation so are preferred over indinavir.

questions.text: Not true about 'Struvite Stones' is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Struvite stone are also known as tripple phosphate stones as they are formed by the phosphate salt of Ca, Mg and NH3. These are dirty white stones which tend to grow along the calyceal system and so they cause the renal problems of obstruction late , by the time they are diagnosed they have mostly reached a very big size and have grown along the calyces till the upper part of ureter, this appears like a Staghorn which is present in on the head of a deer. So they are called staghorn calculus . They are formed in the presence of a urinary tract infection in most of the cases and the most common organism responsible is proteus. They are formed in alkaline urine not the acidic urine.

questions.text: Randall's plaques causes: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Randall’s plaque is microscopically a plaque of calcium deposited in the interstitial tissue of the renal papilla. These plaques are thought to serve as a nidus for urinary stone formation.

questions.text: Oxalate stones are found in: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Calcium oxalate stones are formed in presence of hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria and hyper oxaluria. One more thing you should remember is that ethylene glycol toxicity can lead to calcium oxalate stone formation. Ethanol, diethy glycol and methyl alcohol are not associated with stone formation.

questions.text: Staghorn calculus is made of: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Struvite stone are also known as triple phosphate stones as they are formed by the phosphate salt of Ca, Mg and NH3. These are dirty white stones which tend to grow along the calyceal system and so they cause the renal problems of obstruction late , by the time they are diagnosed they have mostly reached a very big size and have grown along the calyces till the upper part of ureter, this appears like a Staghorn which is present in on the head of a deer. So they are called staghorn calculus . They are formed in the presence of a urinary tract infection in most of the cases and the most common organism responsible is proteus Oxalate, uric acid and cysteine are not present in Staghorn calculus

questions.text: Renal stones which are laminated and irregular in outline are: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Calcium oxalate stones are irregular and laminated.

choices.text: Junction of ureter and renal pelvis
At crossing of gonadal vessels and ureter

questions.text: Locate the renal stone with pain radiating to medial side of thigh and perineum due to slipping of stone in males:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pain is the most common symptom of the renal stone. Pain can be dull aching constant pain at the renal angles or it can a radiating pain. Depending on the position of the stone in the urinary tract the pain can radiate to different locations : If stone is at the junction of renal pelvis or the upper ureter: Patients have a typical Loin to Groin radiation of pain. If stone is in the upper ureter or at pelvic brim : Patients experience radiation of pain towards the medial aspect of thigh and perineum. This pain radiates along the obturator nerve. If stone comes to lie in the middle ureter: Pain radiates to the hypogastric region and this pain radiates along the iliohypogastric nerve If stone is in the lower ureter: Pain may radiate along the inguinal canal upto testis . This radiation of pain is along the Ilio inguinal nerve . If the pain is in the intramural part of the bladder then patients can have something which is known as stangury , this means that patient has a intense desire to pass the urine but patient is not anble to pass the urine, all patient passes is few drops of blood.

questions.text: All are radio opaque except one: (AIIMS Nov 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Three broad categories of stones are described, based on their X-ray appearance. Radio-opaque:- Opacity implies presence of substantial amounts of calcium within the stone. Calcium phosphate stones are the most radiodense stones, almost as dense as bone. Calcium oxalate stones are slightly less radiodense. Relatively radiolucent: Cystine stones are relatively radiodense because they contain sulfur . Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones are less radiodense than calcium containing stones. Completely radiolucent: Uric acid, triamterene, xanthine, indinavir stones are in this category (cannot be seen even on CTU).

questions.text: What complication should one expect when PCNL is done through 11th intercostals space? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PCNL stands for percutaneous nephrolithotomy and it is a procedure done for the treatment of renal stones which are more than 2 cm in size. In this what we do is we create a track from skin to the calyces of the kidney, introduce a nephroscope in the calyces of kidney, then we try to break the stones into small pieces and then we remove the fragments, some of the fragments are washed away in the urine. As we have to make a track from skin to the kidney most common complication of PCNL is hematoma formation. As this a blind procedure done under C-Arm there is a high chance of injury to the structures. We can end up injuring Pleura, colon and spleen. Pleura is most commonly injured and patients develop pneumothorax. Coming back to this question as the question says we approached through 11th intercostal space there is a high chance of injuring the underlying pleura and leading to Pneumothorax. Hematuria can commonly occur with this procedure too but in this question there is higher chance of pleural injury.

choices.text: It has a wave length of 2100 nm
Its use for cysteine stones has caused deaths due to generation of cyanide
It is effective against the hardest urinary stones
It can even cut the wire of stone baskets

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Holmium: YAG laser is incorrect? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Holmium YAG laser has a wavelength of 2100 nm and at this wavelength it is absorbed by all the stones but not by the surrounding tissue. The zone of thermal injury from Holmium YAG laser ranges from 0.5 to 1 mm. Holmium YAG lithotripsy occurs mainly by the photothermal mechanism which causes evaporation of the stones so it is helpful even for the hard stones. Holmium YAG laser should be used with care with metallic wires and dormia basket as it can lead to thermal disfiguaration of these wires and baskets and prevent their easy removal and sometimes even cut these wires. When Holmium YAG laser is used for cysteine stones there occurs formation of cyanide, but the good part is patients do not suffer from cyanide toxicity so they it can be used safely for cysteine stones also.

questions.text: Percentage of renal stones which are radio opaque: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Note that 90 % of the renal stones are radio opaque on the other hand only 10 % of the gall stones are radio opaque. This is the reason why we carry out X-ray KUB as a screening test for patients with suspected renal calculi as 90 % of them are radio opaque and X-ray serves is a good screening tool.

questions.text: Which one of the following is radiolucent stone? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C that is uric acid stone is a radiolucent stone. Other radiolucent stones are Xanthine, uric acid, triamterene and indinavir. Calcium oxalate, cysteine and phosphate are not radiolucent they are radio opaque. Three broad categories of stones are described, based on their X-ray appearance. Radio-opaque: Opacity implies presence of substantial amounts of calcium within the stone. Calcium phosphate stones are the mos radiodense stones, almost as dense as bone. Calcium oxalate stones are slightly less radiodense. Relatively radiolucent: Cystine stones are relatively radiodense because they contain sulfur. Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones are less radiodense than calcium containing stones. Completely radiolucent: Uric acid, triamterene, xanthine, indinavir stones are in this category (cannot be seen even on CTU).

questions.text: AII are risk factors for nephrolithiasis except (DNB 2007)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Excessive intake of calcium in the diet is not a risk factor for renal stone formation as absorption of calcium from the GIT is regulated and under feedback control. Option A that is renal tubular acidosis is a risk factor for nephrolithiasis Option B that is high protein diet is a risk factor for renal stone specifically for uric acid stone so we advise low purine diet in patients of uric acid stone. Option D that is hypercalciuria is a risk factor for calcium oxalate stone.

questions.text: Staghorn calculus is made of: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Staghorn calculi is made up of Calcium, ammonium and magnesium phosphate and are known as triple phosphate stones. Staghorn calculi is not made up of oxalate, uric acid or cysteine. Struvite stones occupying atleast 20% pelvicalceal system are known as Staghorn Calculus.

questions.text: Chandu, 45-year old male shows calcification on the right side of his abdomen in an AP view. In lateral view the calcification is seen to overlie the spine. Most likely diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This question talks about the calcification seen on right side of the abdomen in AP view and in lateral view it overlies the spine. This finding is suggestive of renal stone. If the question talks about the calcification seen on AP view and on lateral view it lies away from the spine it might indicate a gall bladder stone but only 10% of gall bladder stones are radio opaque.

questions.text: Stone which is resistant to lithotripsy? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cystine stone is relatively a hard stone so it is resistant to lithotripsy. Stones which are relatively resistant to lithotripsy can be remembered by a mnemonic “ Have CCB” Have: Hypoxanthine C: Calcium oxalate monohydrate C: Cystine B: Brushite. ESWL is the preferred treatment option for Ca oxalate dihydrate, triple phosphate stone and uric acid stone.

choices.text: Involves the placement of a hollow needle into the renal colleting system through the soft tissue of the loin and the renal parenchyma
Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track
Perforation of the collecting system may occur

questions.text: Following is true about PCNL except (MHSSN/ICET 2009)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is a technique used to treat larger stones in the renal pelvis or calyces but is sometimes also employed to deal with stones in the proximal ureter. During PCNL, a tract is established into the renal collecting system using ultrasound or fluoroscopic guidance. A series of dilators is used followed by placement of a working sheath into the collecting system through which the stone is visualised and fragmented Complications relating to PCNL include: 1 Injury to the spleen, pleura and colon. 2 Haemorrhage from usually the renal parenchyma but also from major renal vessels. If the latter occurs, the treatment of choice is embolisation but, if this doesn’t work, nephrectomy very occasionally has to be considered. 3 Sepsis. 4 Extravasation due to rupture of the collecting system. 5 Retained stone fragments. 6 Open surgery to the kidney is sometimes more complicated after PCNL.

questions.text: Most common cause of emphysematous pyelonephritis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common cause of emphysematous pyelonephritis is E.Coli. Most common cause of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is Proteus. Most common cause of emphysematous cholecystitis is Clostridium Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is not an infective condition it is caused by rupture of Rokitansky Aschoff sinuses and inflammatory changes surrounding it.

questions.text: Following is true of pyonephrosis except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pyonephrosis develops in a chronically obstructed kidney. Most common cause of obstruction is a stone disease and most common stone is struvite stone. There occurs acute pyelonephritis and stagnated urine and collection. The stagnated collection gets infected and in later stages destroys renal parenchyma converting kidney into a bag of pus . Option B is wrong as stones can be present in both the kidneys leading to formation of B/L pyonephrosis in patients who neglect the disease and defer the treatment.

questions.text: Subcapsular nephrectomy is indicated in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pyonephrosis is defined a kidney which has been converted into a bag of pus. So the treatment of this condition is subcapsular nephrectomy. Option A is perinephric abscess and it is treated with antibiotics and resuscitation followed by external drainage of the abscess and in advanced cases we go for nephrectomy. Option B is hydronephrosis it is treated with pyeloplasty or endopyelotomy. Option D is solitary adenocarcinoma, we can go for partial or complete nephrectomy as the treatment option depending on the condition of contralateral kidney.

questions.text: Unilateral hydronephrosis is due to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ureterocele involves individual ureter so it can lead to unilateral hydronephrosis. Bladder neck stenosis, urethral stricture and carcinoma prostate can lead to bilateral hydronephrosis .

questions.text: Most common route of infection in kidney tuberculosis: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tuberculosis in the renal system is always secondary. In patients there is a foci of mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria in the lungs and these organisms can reach the urogenital system via hematogenous route. Mycobacterium bacteria traverses in the blood and first affects Kidney and Prostate. Rest all the structures in the urogenital system are affected either by the ascent or descent of the infection from the kidney and prostate. Lymphatic spread as a source of mycobacterium TB in urogenital system is rare.

questions.text: The most sensitive imaging modality to detect early renal tuberculosis is : (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CT is the most sensitive modality for visualising renal calcifications and CT urography is more sensitive at identifying all manifestations of renal tuberculosis:

choices.text: AFB in early morning sample is always positive

questions.text: In genitourinary TB, true is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Once the mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria reaches kidney via the blood stream it gets concentrated at the periglomerular capillaries. Then it leads to formation of cortical granuloma which converts into a cortical abscess. Over a course of time it ruptures in the pelvicalyceal system and we get this in urine. When we examine the urine of such patients on microscopic examination, we can see plenty of pus cells but we are not able to see the bacteria. This is called sterile pyuria. It is a consistent finding of genitourinary TB. AFB can be found in morning samples but are not positive always so to increase the sensitivity of the test we do 3 consecutive exams of early morning urine samples. MC site is not the pelvis but it is the renal papillae . It is one of the causes of pyelonephritis but not the most common cause.

questions.text: Earliest and often the only presentation of TB kidney is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Increased frequency of urination is the earliest and often the only presentation of TB of kidney. Pain and hematuria can develop but are not a consistent features and renal stone in a tubercular kidney is a rare finding.

questions.text: Sterile pyuria is characteristically seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Once the mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria reaches kidney via the blood stream it gets concentrated at the periglomerular capillaries. Then it leads to formation of cortical granuloma which converts into a cortical abscess. Over a course of time it ruptures in the pelvicalyceal system and we get this in urine. When we examine the urine of such patients on microscopic examination we can see plenty of pus cells but we are not able to see the bacteria. This is called sterile pyuria. It is a consistent finding of genitourinary TB

questions.text: An arteriogram is performed on a patient with atherosclerosis. Luminal narrowing of which of the following vessels would compromise blood flow through the renal arteries?
questions.solution: Correct answer (A) The renal arteries emerge from the abdominal aorta at about the level of the L1/L2 intervertebral disc and travel at nearly right angles to it (on the right, passing posterior to the inferior vena cava to enter the hilum of the kidney.
